solution_line_template: If he sold a painting at a {painting_loss_percentage} loss, then he made a {painting_loss_percentage}*${painting_cost} = $<<{painting_loss_percentage}*{painting_cost}={loss_per_painting}>>{loss_per_painting} loss on each painting.

since he bought {num_paintings} paintings, the total loss he made from selling the paintings is {num_paintings}*${loss_per_painting} = $<<{num_paintings}*{loss_per_painting}={total_loss_paintings}>>{total_loss_paintings}
He also made a loss of {toy_loss_percentage}*{toy_cost} = $<<{toy_loss_percentage}*{toy_cost}={loss_per_toy}>>{loss_per_toy} loss from selling each wooden toy.
Since he bought {num_toys} wooden toys, the total loss he made was {loss_per_toy}*{num_toys} = $<<{num_toys}*{loss_per_toy}={total_loss_toys}>>{total_loss_toys}
In total, Mr. Callen made a loss of ${total_loss_paintings}+${total_loss_toys} = $<<{total_loss_paintings}+{total_loss_toys}={total_loss}>>{total_loss} from the sales of the items.
